title.narrative: Make Way Programme

description.narrative: Make Way programme_RF_MFA

Make Way, embracing intersectionality for health equity & justice.
The Make Way programme (2021-2025) (previously 'the Intersectionality Consortium') aims to ensure youth in all their diversity can fully realise their sexual and reproductive health and rights (SRHR). We promote an intersectional approach to addressing SRHR issues. This means making overlapping vulnerabilities visible to understand their effects on people’s SRHR. We develop innovative tools and build capacities of other civil society organisations to advocate the needed policy and societal changes.
Our partnership consists of Akina Mama wa Afrika, The Circle of Concerned African Women Theologians, Forum for African Women Educationalists, Liliane Foundation, VSO Netherlands, and Wemos, and we work in partnership with the Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
We implement Make Way in Ethiopia, Kenya, Rwanda, Uganda, Zambia, and at the Eastern and Southern African region and global level.
1st disbursement, by Wemos as budget holder / recipient organisation from DGIS, to Wemos for the implementation of the Make Way programme and for the budget of the Programme Coordination Unit.
1st disbursement, by Wemos to Akina Mama wa Afrika, for the implementation of the Make Way programme.
1st disbursement, by Wemos to Forum for African Women Educationalists (FAWE), for the implementation of the Make Way programme.
1st disbursement, by Wemos to Liliane Foundation, for the implementation of the Make Way programme.
1st disbursement, by Wemos to VSO Netherlands, for the implementation of the Make Way programme. This includes funds for the implementation by the Circle of Concerned African Women Theologians.
Contractual commitment between Wemos and Akina Mama wa Afrika to provide the specified amount of funds, for the Make Way programme implementation.
Contractual commitment between Wemos and FAWE to provide the specified amount of funds, for the Make Way programme implementation.
Contractual commitment between Wemos and Liliane Foundation to provide the specified amount of funds, for the Make Way programme implementation.

Contractual commitment between Wemos and VSO Netherlands to provide the specified amount of funds, for the Make Way programme implementation. This includes funds for the implementation by the Circle of Concerned African Women Theologians.
Contractual commitment between Wemos as budget holder, to Wemos for the implementation of Make Way and for the budget of the Programme Coordination Unit, to provide the specified amount of funds.
First instalment for the Make Way programme, made from the NL MFA to Wemos.
Second instalment for the Make Way programme, made from the NL MFA to Wemos.
Total commitment from DGIS to Wemos, as penholder of the Make Way consortium, to implement the Make Way programme from 2021-2025.

title.narrative: Photo by Git Stephen Gitau
MakeWay_AnnualReport2021
MT SO 4: The Make Way collaborating partners have the confidence, voice and agency to undertake intersectional SRHR advocacy

description.narrative: Having confidence, voice and agency equals the fourth stage of the decision-making process: Implementation

title.narrative: MT SO 4.1.a: # of advocacy initiatives initiated by Make Way collaborating partners, with others (national and international levels)

description.narrative:
Advocacy initiative: An advocacy initiative for SRHR, including an intersectional lens. An advocacy initiative can be a public campaign, a policy brief written and submitted to the authority concerned, research to generate evidence, initiation of influencing processes, etc. An initiative is a distinct set of actions with a pre-set objective.
Initiated: Carrying out, based on the gained resources and the opportunity to apply gained knowledge and skills.
With others: With their membership/constituency
​
Reporting at BL, ML, EL, on unique values. For national and international level initiatives.
​
L:inks with MFA SCS4:
- **SCS041 # of advocacy initiatives carried out by CSOs, for, by or with their membership/constituency**

comment.narrative:
As part of our baseline analyses, we performed context analyses in which we looked at the status of SRHR and health among young people, access to SRH(R) information and services, and how health system factors affect the SRHR of young people. We then looked at how socio-political factors affect youth SRHR, including gender norms, youth involvement in policy processes, and the scope and quality of relevant strategies, policies and plans. We also studied the impact of COVID-19 in our different implementation contexts, the challenges and opportunities for civic space, CSO capacity, and how our programme relates to conflict sensitivity in each context. We assessed both immediate and structural causes of poor SRHR outcomes and analysed the disconnect between actual community needs and national, regional and global priority-setting in health and other sectors.
We selected our collaborating partners (CPs) in each implementation context. CPs were selected based on their work content, constituencies and catchment areas, and their track records in SRHR, advocacy, youth engagement and leadership. The CPs that committed to the programme, took part in the co-creation process for the context-specific programmes. Workshops were held in the five countries and in the regional and global context, during which the scope of the contextualised programmes was defined and the ToC were developed. Then, results frameworks and activity work plans were developed.
The context-specific work plans include the advocacy initiatives that we have planned for 2022 and the results frameworks specify in what areas and at what levels we will measure our advocacy successes.
In 2022, we will further strengthen our ways of working (together) by (1) developing a detailed stakeholder engagement strategy and plan; (2) carrying out opposition analyses; and (3) developing detailed lobby and advocacy plans.
Establishment of baseline, setting targets and reporting on actuals at BL, ML and EL.
Establishment of baseline, setting targets and reporting on actuals at BL, ML and EL.
Establishment of baseline, setting targets and reporting on actuals at BL, ML and EL.

End-line target.
The proposed advocacy initiatives for the duration of the programme focus on a wide array of topics. The following list of topics is a selection of what we will be focusing on in our implementation contexts. Note that not all topics will be addressed (as extensively) in each context.
· Using social accountability tools/mechanisms in holding duty bearers accountable for their commitments and/or responsibilities
· Support and strengthen legal and policy frameworks on disability
· Campaigning initiatives for revision, passage, implementation of the East African Community Sexual and Reproductive Health Bill
· Eastern and Southern Africa (ESA) Ministerial Commitment on sexuality education and sexual and reproductive health services for adolescents and young people
· Promote the development of sexual harassment/safeguarding policies in schools, higher education institutions and workplaces
· Advocate improvements of (intersectional) SRHR budgets
· Promote the use of intersectional disaggregated data on SRHR
· Advocate health care workers capacity strengthening on intersectionality to increase AAAQ of SRH services
· Advocate changes in funding structures and policies on SRHR for marginalised youth
· Promote inclusive ESA commitments on comprehensive sexuality education
· Advocate increased international financing for Covid-19, supporting health systems and maintaining essential (SR) health services
· Increasing transparency and accountability of donors and development partners in official development assistance and development financing
· Influence global strategies of development partners or donors to support a public first approach to health financing
· Support greater harmonisation of global strategies with national strategies, in terms of priorities and funding

title.narrative: MT SO 4.1.b: # of advocacy initiatives initiated by Make Way collaborating partners, with others (sub-national level)

description.narrative:

Initiated: Carrying out, based on the gained resources and the opportunity to apply gained knowledge and skills.
With others: With their membership/constituency

Reporting at BL, ML, EL, on unique values. For sub-national level initiatives.
​
Links with MFA SCS4:
- **SCS042 # of advocacy initiatives carried out by CSOs, for, by or with their membership/constituency at sub-national level**

Establishment of baseline, setting targets and reporting on actuals at BL, ML and EL.

End-line target.
The proposed advocacy initiatives for the duration of the programme focus on a wide array of topics. The following list of topics is a selection of what we will be focusing on in our implementation contexts. Note that not all topics will be addressed (as extensively) in each context.

title.narrative: MT SO 4.2.b: # of CSOs (not youth- or women-led) that have become more inclusive

description.narrative:
More inclusive:
- integrate intersectional advocacy approaches in our work; - represent more marginalised youth with compounded vulnerabilities; - have the knowledge, capacity, support and networks to self-organise and help scale-up intersectionality advocacy approaches to SRHR.
Reporting annually, on reach values, of non-youth or women-led CSOs (collaborating partners).
​
Links with MFA SCS 8:
- **SCS083 # of CSOs (not youth led or women led) using a Gender and Social Inclusion lens during all phases of the programming cycle with specific attention to youth.**

comment.narrative:
The Make Way programme aims to get to the root of the problem of why young people facing compounded vulnerabilities, are at a higher risk of facing discrimination and exclusion from mainstream SRHR services, policies and planning. By applying an intersectional lens, we can identify how interlocking vulnerabilities exacerbate barriers, and what societal and systemic changes are necessary to overcome these. It will also help us assess assumptions, biases, beliefs and power imbalances, and determine how these affect both traditional and modern SRH practices of young people facing compounded vulnerabilities.
Our aim is for our efforts, and our organisations, to become more inclusive to lead to greater (social) accountability towards giving the most vulnerable access to quality SRH services, stronger health systems and multi-sectoral policies that lead to equity and social justice.
We define ‘organisations become more inclusive’ as follows:
- integrate intersectional advocacy approaches in our work; - represent more youth with compounded vulnerabilities; - have the knowledge, capacity, support and networks to self-organise and help scale-up intersectionality advocacy approaches to SRHR.
In order to contribute to greater (social) accountability, we as consortium partners need to play an exemplary role and understand our own biases, assumptions and approaches.
We developed a values self-assessment survey and carried it out among consortium partners. The survey comprises two main parts: a values clarification, and a rapid organisational audit (on organisational culture and practice, policies, governance and budget in place to support gender justice, equity, inclusion and diversity).
Based on feedback from consortium partners, on taking the values self-assessment survey, we will adjust the self-assessment format. In 2022, our collaborating partners will have an opportunity to complete the values self-assessment.
Target to be set in 2022.
Target to be set in 2023.
Target to be set in 2024.

title.narrative: LT SO 5: Make Way CSO allies are more inclusive; their joint efforts make the need for intersectional SRHR more visible and credible
LT SO 5.2.a: # of joint intersectional SRHR advocacy initiatives implemented by Make Way CSO allies (national and international levels)

description.narrative:
Joint: More than one organisation. Representing at least 2 constituencies.
Advocacy initiative: An advocacy initiative for SRHR, including an intersectional lens. An advocacy initiative can be a public campaign, a policy brief written and submitted to the authority concerned, research to generate evidence, initiation of influencing processes, etc. An initiative is a distinct set of actions with a pre-set objective
Implemented: Activities conducted based on plans.
Reporting at BL (2023) and EL (2025), on unique values. For national and international level advocacy initiatives by CSO allies.
​
Links with MFA SCS 4:
**SCS041 - # of advocacy initiatives carried out by CSOs, for, by or with their membership/constituency**

comment.narrative: Baseline set at 2023, as this indicator relates to CSO allies - which will only become part of the Make Way programme during year 3.
Target for 2025 to be set in 2023.

title.narrative: LT SO 3: Make Way CSO allies have the requisite capacity for intersectional SRHR advocacy
LT SO 3.1.b: # of Make Way CSO allies (not youth- or women-led) with increased advocacy capacities for intersectional SRHR

description.narrative:
The number of CSO allies with increased advocacy capacities for intersectional SRHR.
Capacity: (knowledge, skill, attitude)
- Knowing what intersectional SRHR advocacy is, and how to integrate into their work and organisation - Understanding power dynamics at play that could affect their advocacy actions on SRHR and intersectionality - Key policies affecting national decision-making and budget allocations on SRHR and intersectionality - Formulating their own advocacy asks related to SRH and the channels used for raising their issues - Knowing how to meaningfully engage youth throughout the advocacy cycle
​
Reporting annually, on unique values, for not youth- or women-led CSO allies.
​
Links with SRHR indicator J:
**SRH023 - # of CSOs (not youth or women led) with increased L&A capacities**

comment.narrative: To be determined, if applicable.
To be determined in 2023.
To be determined in 2024.

title.narrative: MT SO 3: The Make Way collaborating partners have the requisite capacity for intersectional SRHR advocacy
MT SO 3.1.a: # of Make Way collaborating partners (youth-led) with increased advocacy capacities

description.narrative:
The number of collaborating partners with increased advocacy capacities for intersectional SRHR.
​
Capacity: (knowledge, skill, attitude)
- Knowing what intersectional SRHR advocacy is, and how to integrate into their work and organisation - Understanding power dynamics at play that could affect their advocacy actions on SRHR and intersectionality - Key policies affecting national decision-making and budget allocations on SRHR and intersectionality - Formulating their own advocacy asks related to SRH and the channels used for raising their issues - Knowing how to meaningfully engage youth throughout the advocacy cycle
Reporting annually, on unique values, for youth-led collaborating partners.
​
Links with SRHR indicator J:
**SRH022 - # of youth led CSOs with increased L&A capacities**

comment.narrative:
The assessment reveals that CPs are keen to apply an intersectional lens and learn how to do this. E.g. CPs want to learn how to include the ‘most marginalised groups in the community’ and how to approach inclusion from an intersectional perspective. There is a strong perceived need to ensure advocacy benefits ‘people from marginalised communities’. Also, they want to learn how to developed sharper policy analysis and more strategic advocacy plans that are responsive to the needs of young people and focus on the right priorities.
Many CPs indicate they would like to improve their data-gathering and evidence-building. Some are keen to strengthen their capacity to identify trends in SRHR and youth; others want to do research to know who is not being included and why. Some want to get ‘grassroots evidence’ to improve their advocacy strategies and there is a desire to identify research gaps on structural and systemic health system failures.
In most contexts, partners are confident about their movement-building and stakeholder management but would like support to engage with new types of actors.
Almost all CPs working at country level want better communications and media strategies, and better M&E of these. They want to know how to engage with media representatives and create more targeted messaging, including messages aimed at opponents. Also, there is a need to identify which messages and formats work best for sharing knowledge and raising awareness.
Lastly, almost all CPs across the contexts want to learn how to do a better job at identifying and prioritising risks in relation to advocacy goals and working with vulnerable youth. CPs want to learn how to mitigate these risks with safety, security and safeguarding approaches.
Based on the indicated desires or needs for (further) strengthening of knowledge, skills or resources to perform intersectional SRHR advocacy, the CPs are finalising their capacity strengthening action plans.
Target to be set in 2022.
Target to be set in 2023.
Target to be set in 2024.

Almost all CPs working at country level want better communications and media strategies, and better M&E of these. title.narrative: LT outcome: A critical and growing mass of duty-bearers and society at large actively supports intersectional SRHR
LT outcome A.a: # of times agenda setting and influencing the debate related to SRHR and intersectionality, raised by CSOs, takes place among duty bearers (national and international levels)

description.narrative:
Count the number of times that duty-bearers set the agenda and/or influence the debate related to SRHR and intersectionality, based on the issues raised by CSOs, at national and international levels.
In the comment section, describe what activities were undertaken by the CSOs to influence this, and in what ways the duty-bearers set the agenda/influenced the debate.
​
Agenda setting: Targeted actors place CSO issues on the agenda
Influencing the debate: Targeted actors adopt CSO terminology, rhetoric and framing
Duty Bearers: Those responsible for fulfilling SRHR
CSO: Make Way collaborating partners / CSO allies
​
Reporting at BL, ML, EL, on unique values.
​
Links with MFA SCS 3:
- **SCS031 # of times that CSOs succeed in creating space for CSO demands and positions through agenda setting, influencing the debate and/or creating space to engage at national and international level**

comment.narrative:
The ability of civil society actors to advocate for SRHR faces major challenges. In some countries, such as Ethiopia, the legal environment for CSOs remains severely restrictive. In Rwanda, the government and CSOs are engaged in a policy dialogue, but CSO participation in policy-and decision- making processes is government-controlled; ‘critical CSOs’ face being shut down. In Uganda, the government curtails the freedom of expression and assembly of CSOs by distorting existing security laws; in other cases, certain CSOs are simply closed down. In somewhat more amenable environments, as in Kenya, where there is an active civil-society sector, human rights non- governmental organisations (NGOs) are heavily undermined in their operations, especially around elections.
CSO capacity is constrained. Funding has been cut across the board and the funding that local CSOs obtain is inadequate to cover the majority of youth initiatives. In Kenya, CSOs fill gaps in essential service provision and take on important SRHR advocacy, yet they do not receive adequate funding. In Ethiopia, the civil-society sector is fairly new, and CSOs work in silos. In Rwanda, CSO policy influencing is limited, due to the aforementioned repression, but the quality of CSO advocacy work is also inadequate.
Antagonism to SRHR from powerful conservative or authoritarian governments and churches, for example, poses challenges to the ability of civil society actors to advocate for SRHR. For example, at an African regional level, Roman Catholic bishops oppose the Maputo Protocol because it defines abortion as a human right. In the international arena, opposition groups are well-organised and block space for progressive civil society and rights groups.
Establishment of baseline, setting targets and reporting on actuals at BL, ML and EL.
Establishment of baseline, setting targets and reporting on actuals at BL, ML and EL.
Establishment of baseline, setting targets and reporting on actuals at BL, ML and EL.

End-line target.
​
Across our implementation contexts, we are striving after strengthened engagements between CSOs and duty bearers, and meaningful civil society contributions to the fulfilment of SRHR of minoritized youths. We are seeking to being present in meetings of duty bearers and to be on the(ir) agenda with our issues. We want to advocate the usage of evidence-based information and data, in order to inform decision-making processes on (intersectional) SRH.
Also, we seek to widen civic space for youth facing compounded vulnerabilities. We will advocate meaningful youth participation by participating in and supporting forums or meetings that support this, both at national and at sub-national levels. Where appropriate, we will have advocacy actions led by youth (with compounded vulnerabilities), for inclusive SRHR.

title.narrative: LT outcome A.b: # of times agenda setting and influencing the debate related to SRHR and intersectionality, raised by CSOs, takes place among duty bearers (sub-national level)

description.narrative:
Count the number of times that duty-bearers set the agenda and/or influence the debate related to SRHR and intersectionality, based on the issues raised by CSOs, at sub-national level.
In the comment section, describe what activities were undertaken by the CSOs to influence this, and in what ways the duty-bearers set the agenda/influenced the debate.
Agenda setting: Targeted actors place CSO issues on the agenda
Influencing the debate: Targeted actors adopt CSO terminology, rhetoric and framing
Duty Bearers: Those responsible for fulfilling SRHR
CSO: Make Way collaborating partners / CSO allies
​
Reporting at BL, ML, EL, on unique values.
​
Links with MFA SCS 3:
- **SCS032 # of times that CSOs succeed in creating space for CSO demands and positions through agenda setting, influencing the debate and/or creating space to engage at sub-national level**

comment.narrative:
The ability of civil society actors to advocate for SRHR faces major challenges. In some countries, such as Ethiopia, the legal environment for CSOs remains severely restrictive. In Rwanda, the government and CSOs are engaged in a policy dialogue, but CSO participation in policy-and decision- making processes is government-controlled; ‘critical CSOs’ face being shut down. In Uganda, the government curtails the freedom of expression and assembly of CSOs by distorting existing security laws; in other cases, certain CSOs are simply closed down. In somewhat more amenable environments, as in Kenya, where there is an active civil-society sector, human rights non- governmental organisations (NGOs) are heavily undermined in their operations, especially around elections.
CSO capacity is constrained. Funding has been cut across the board and the funding that local CSOs obtain is inadequate to cover the majority of youth initiatives. In Kenya, CSOs fill gaps in essential service provision and take on important SRHR advocacy, yet they do not receive adequate funding. In Ethiopia, the civil-society sector is fairly new, and CSOs work in silos. In Rwanda, CSO policy influencing is limited, due to the aforementioned repression, but the quality of CSO advocacy work is also inadequate.
Antagonism to SRHR from powerful conservative or authoritarian governments and churches, for example, poses challenges to the ability of civil society actors to advocate for SRHR. For example, at an African regional level, Roman Catholic bishops oppose the Maputo Protocol because it defines abortion as a human right. In the international arena, opposition groups are well-organised and block space for progressive civil society and rights groups.
Establishment of baseline, setting targets and reporting on actuals at BL, ML and EL.
Establishment of baseline, setting targets and reporting on actuals at BL, ML and EL.
Establishment of baseline, setting targets and reporting on actuals at BL, ML and EL.

End-line target.
​
Across our implementation contexts, we are striving after strengthened engagements between CSOs and duty bearers, and meaningful civil society contributions to the fulfilment of SRHR of minoritized youths. We are seeking to being present in meetings of duty bearers and to be on the(ir) agenda with our issues. We want to advocate the usage of evidence-based information and data, in order to inform decision-making processes on (intersectional) SRH.
Also, we seek to widen civic space for youth facing compounded vulnerabilities. We will advocate meaningful youth participation by participating in and supporting forums or meetings that support this, both at national and at sub-national levels. Where appropriate, we will have advocacy actions led by youth (with compounded vulnerabilities), for inclusive SRHR.

title.narrative: By-laws for sustainable inclusive development, that impact intersectional SRHR, are in place

comment.narrative:
The policy and legal environment in Make Way implementation countries is not conducive to youth SRHR. Policies proliferate, but are not implemented either well or consistently. In some cases, whole categories of vulnerable young people are left out of policies: people living with disability are missing from various policies and strategies, and none of the national strategies and policies mentions transgender and intersex persons. In one of our implementation countries, although there is an adolescent health roadmap that provides for access to contraception, free of charge in the public health sector and without any legal age restriction, it is forbidden to distribute contraceptives in schools.
At regional and global level, for example, the East African Community SRH Draft Bill 2021 remains silent on the SRHR of sex workers and LGBTQI+ people. In addition, rights language was eliminated from the title of the Bill, although it remains in the body of the Bill. We also see evidence of a great deal of influence exerted by external actors that distorts country-owned allocation decisions. The sources of such external influence include global health initiatives, such as the Global Fund (GF) and the Global Financing Facility (GFF), international financing initiatives, such as the World Bank, and bilateral donors and other funders.
Establishment of baseline, setting targets and reporting on actuals at BL, ML and EL.
Establishment of baseline, setting targets and reporting on actuals at BL, ML and EL.
Establishment of baseline, setting targets and reporting on actuals at BL, ML and EL.

At regional and global level, for example, the East African Community SRH Draft Bill 2021 remains silent on the SRHR of sex workers and LGBTQI+ people. In addition, rights language was eliminated from the title of the Bill, although it remains in the body of the Bill. The sources of such external influence include global health initiatives, such as the Global Fund (GF) and the Global Financing Facility (GFF), international financing initiatives, such as the World Bank, and bilateral donors and other funders.

In some cases, whole categories of vulnerable young people are left out of policies: people living with disability are missing from various policies and strategies, and none of the national strategies and policies mentions transgender and intersex persons.
